page.title: 03BOUNDARIES NEAR STUBHAMPTON
page.content: The parish boundary around Fontmell Magna was first written down in a charter of c.888 AD and has remained little changed today. Many landmarks cited then exiist now including boundaries, copses and barrows. One such copse is "Sutton Clump" at the top of Sutton Hill. Iron Age cross dykes believed to mark cattle/farm boundaries are found in the woods. From medieval times there remains terracing known as strip lynchetts - locally as "lanches". Today many field boundaries remain from the various periods of enclosure and the hedges have a diversity of natural life. In the exppansion of mechanised agriculture in the past 3 decades some hedges have gone and the increased use of chemicals has reduced the flora in others.
